exitSurvey.q: In general, do you think it is more important to consider whether a patient is responsible for their own kidney failure OR how long a patient is expected to live if they receive a kidney when deciding which patient should be prioritized for a transplant?
a: I think the patient's responsibility for their own organ failure is much more important than their life expectancy
I think the patient's responsibility for their own organ failure is somewhat more important than their life expectancy
I think responsibility and life expectancy are equally important
I think the patient's life expectancy is somewhat more important than responsibility for their own organ failure
I think the patient's life expectancy is much more important than responsibility for their own organ failure

exitSurvey.q: Have you ever been part of a kidney transplant?
Have you ever been part of a non-kidney organ transplant?
What is your race/ethnicity? Choose as many as apply.
What is the highest degree or level of school you have completed? If currently enrolled, please mark the previous grade or highest degree received.
a: High school graduate (diploma or a legally accepted equivalent)
Professional degree, such as MD, DDS, DVM, LLB, JD
Doctorate degree, such as PhD, EdD

exitSurvey.q: In these scenarios, did patients’ drinking or drug habits influence their life expectancy?
a: no, patients’ habits did not influence their life expectancy,
yes, patients’ habits influenced their life expectancy
it is unclear whether patients’ habits influenced their life expectancy

exitSurvey.q: In these scenarios, did patients stop drinking or using drugs after being diagnosed with a kidney disease?
a: no, all patients continued drinking or using drugs after diagnosis.
some but not all patients stop drinking or using drugs after diagnosis.
yes, all patients stop drinking or using drugs after diagnosis.
